item.title: U.S. Moves to Cool Indiaâ€™s Rage Over Arrested Diplomat
item.description: The secretary of state expressed regret to a senior Indian official over the incident, in which a female diplomat was arrested and strip-searched.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Devyani Khobragade, the deputy consul general in New York, earlier this month.

item.title: Experts Intrigued by Tidbit in Syrian Chemical Arms Report
item.description: A United Nations panel found the presence of a chemical that can be used in the production of weapons using sarin, in what some outside analysts said could implicate the Syrian government.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Obama Panel Recommends New Limits on N.S.A. Spying
item.description: A panel of presidential advisers who reviewed the National Security Agencyâ€™s surveillance practices urged President Obama on Wednesday to end the governmentâ€™s systematic collection of logs of all Americansâ€™ phone calls.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Ukraineâ€™s Premier Hails Russian Aid, Saying Crisis Has Passed
item.description: The prime minister, Mykola Azarov, said the agreement for Moscow to provide $15 billion in loans and a steep discount on natural gas meant financial crisis had been averted.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pro-government demonstrators on Wednesday in Kiev.

item.title: Local Turf-Sharing Accord With the Taliban Raises Alarm in Afghanistan
item.description: An Afghan Army commander is said to have brokered a turf-sharing deal with the Taliban, a sign of what may come once international troops withdraw.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and TAIMOOR SHAH
item.media:description: An Afghan Army soldier patrolling in the highly contested area of Sangin in August.

item.title: Amnesty Bill In Russia Could Free Activists
item.description: The State Duma passed a bill that seemed to promise freedom for the two jailed members of the punk protest group and 30 demonstrators arrested at an Arctic oil rig.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH
item.media:description: A lawyer for the two Pussy Riot members,Â Maria Alyokhina, left, and Nadia Tolokonnikova, said she expected the women to be released quickly.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Zhang Ziyi Settles Libel Suit and U.S. Website Retracts Story
item.description: A website based in the United States has retracted a series of stories alleging that the Chinese film star Zhang Ziyi slept with powerful men in exchange for money.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: The film star Zhang Ziyi reached an undisclosed settlement with the website that alleged she slept with powerful men in exchange for money.

item.title: Chemical Weapons Agency Unveils Plan for Destroying Syriaâ€™s Stockpile
item.description: The international watchdog overseeing the plan, approved late Tuesday, warned that it faced delays.
item.category: Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Worry in Tunisia Over Youths Who Turn to Jihad
item.description: Concern is growing that hundreds of young Tunisians have been radicalized by Salafist mosques and trained to fight in Syria, with the potential to cause trouble at home.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:description: Tunisian civil defense corps members carried the body of a suicide bomber who blew himself up at a beach near the tourist resort of Sousse in October.

item.title: Letter from India: In India, Using the Ballot Box to Fight Graft
item.description: India is close to legislation that will create a new body to fight corruption. This is a triumph not of mass protests, but of electoral politics.
item.dc:creator: By MANU JOSEPH
item.media:description: Arvind Kejriwal of the Aam Aadmi Party addressing the media in New Delhi last week.

item.title: Shiite Pilgrimage Is Target of Attacks in Iraq
item.description: Pilgrims heading to Karbala to mark Arbaeen were targeted by gunmen and suicide bombers.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: Britain to Join Ranks of Nations Using Plastic Currency
item.description: Canada, Australia and dozens of other countries use polymer bank notes, and the Bank of England has just decided to make the switch.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN and NATHANIEL POPPER
item.media:description: The design for the first polymer note in England â€” a 5-pound bill featuring Winston Churchill â€” was displayed on Wednesday in London.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: December 18
item.description: Indiaâ€™s parliament approved a bill that empowers an independent ombudsman to investigate and prosecute cases of corruption.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Anna Hazare, center, a social activist, ending his hunger strike at Ralegan Siddhi, Maharashtra, after India's parliament passed a contentious anti-graft bill on Wednesday.Â

item.title: Amid Graft Inquiry in Turkey, 5 Police Officials Fired
item.description: A day after the police raided the offices of several businessmen with close ties to Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan, five top police officials were fired, according to media reports.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO and SEBNEM ARSU
item.media:description: Baris Guler, in sunglasses, was one of the sons of cabinet ministers detained in a corruption inquiry that has highlighted tensions between followers of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan and Fethullah Gulen.

item.title: India Ink: Government to Offer Free Fertility Treatments to Create Parsi Baby Boom
item.description: The Jiyo-Parsi Scheme is designed to save the minority community from vanishing in India.
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.dc:creator: By PRIYANKA PATHAK-NARAIN
item.media:description: Kainaz, right, and Farhad Barucha at their apartment in Mumbai, Maharashtra.

item.title: Lawlessness in Borderlands Taints Myanmarâ€™s Progress
item.description: Northern and eastern areas of the country, long riven by ethnic conflict, pose a stubborn impediment to the governmentâ€™s hopes for national peace.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: British Family Rebukes Government Over Surgeonâ€™s Death in Syria
item.description: The physicianâ€™s family accused the British Foreign Office of failing to support him or to help obtain his release.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:credit: Mohammed Al-Khatieb/Agence France-Presse â€” Getty Images
item.media:description: An injured Syrian was assisted Tuesday after an airstrike in Aleppo, where a British surgeon had offered care before being jailed.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Chinese Coal Baron Tumbles into Debt
item.description: Last year a Shanxi coal baron, Xing Libin, spent 70 million renminbi on his daughterâ€™s wedding with jet aircraft for guests, Ferraris and pop stars, Chinese media reported. Now heâ€™s 30 billion renminbi in debt, the government says.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A worker levels the coal on a freight train in Taiyuan in northern China's Shanxi province.

item.title: Ronnie Biggs, Great Train Robber, Dies at 84
item.description: Mr. Biggs gained international fame for his role in one of Britainâ€™s best-known crimes, the Great Train Robbery of 1963, and his subsequent life on the run.
item.dc:creator: By MARGALIT FOX
item.media:description: Mr. Biggs lived as a fugitive for 35 years after his escape from jail while serving a 30-year sentence.

item.title: Lens Blog: Londonâ€™s Streetscapes, Stained by Homicide
item.description: Venturing to the site of a homicide in his neighborhood, a photographer was struck by how ordinary and familiar it was, leading him to explore other such scenes of horrific crimes in London.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID GONZALEZ
item.media:description: Badi Saleem, 35, was stabbed to death at a hostel near King's Cross on May 12, 2011. Marvin Bailey, 42, another hostel resident, was charged with murder, but the court accepted a plea deal after psychiatrists concluded he was a paranoid schizophrenic.

item.title: In Typhoon Area, Kerry Warns of Threats of a Warming Planet
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry toured miles of roofless homes and shattered shantytowns in a Philippine city and announced that additional aid would be sent to the Philippines.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: The city of Tacloban, in the central Philippines, is still recovering from Typhoon Haiyan, one of the most powerful storms ever recorded.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Defense Ministry Issues Statement Playing Down Near Collision at Sea
item.description: In its first official statement on the near collision of Chinese and American warships, the ministry refrained from alleging any improper conduct by the American side.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG

item.title: Indian Parliament Passes Bill Forming Anticorruption Agency
item.description: Setting up such an agency was the central demand of Anna Hazare, a social activist whose fasts and protests electrified the country in 2010.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR and GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: Robert van Zwieten, C.E.O. of Emerging Markets Private Equity Association
item.description: Mr. van Zwieten discussed the outlook for investor appetite in Indian private equity in the coming year.
item.dc:creator: By RAKESH MANI

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Response to Thomas L. Friedmanâ€™s â€˜Letterâ€™ to President Xi
item.description: Global Times, a newspaper belonging to the flagship Peopleâ€™s Daily, has responded with apparent frankness to a column by Thomas L. Friedman, who warned against expelling Western journalists for their reporting on China.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Global Times said that Thomas L. Friedman was out of touch with China's security concerns.
